title: Understanding the Problem
text: To find the pH of a weak base solution, we need to use the base dissociation constant (Kb) and the initial concentration of the base. The assumption that $$x\operatorname{shiftLeft}C$$ helps simplify the calculations.

title: Write the Equilibrium Expression
text: For a weak base B, the equilibrium expression is: B+H2O<->BH+OH. The equilibrium constant expression is $$Kb=\frac{[BH][OH]/[B][BH][OH]/[B]}{[BH][OH]/[B]}$$.

title: Set Up the ICE Table
text: Create an ICE (Initial, Change, Equilibrium) table to track the concentrations of B, BH, and OH at equilibrium. Assume the change in concentration of B is $$-x$$, and for BH and OH, it is $$+x$$.

title: Apply the Assumption
text: Assume $$x\operatorname{shiftLeft}C$$, which means the change in concentration of B is negligible. Therefore, [B] at equilibrium is approximately equal to its initial concentration.

title: Solve for $$x$$
text: Using the equilibrium expression $$Kb=\frac{[BH][OH]/[B][BH][OH]/[B]}{[BH][OH]/[B]}$$, substitute the values and solve for $$x$$, which represents [OH].

title: Calculate pOH
text: Once you have the concentration of OH, calculate the pOH using the formula $$pOH=-log[OH]$$.

title: Convert pOH to pH
text: Use the relationship $$pH+pOH=14$$ to find the pH of the solution.
